Trial_Design.evidence: An open-label randomized clinical trial was performed in 169 patients

Participants.evidence: Patients with 2 or more of the following risk factors were included: overweight or obesity, diagnosis of neoplastic disease, male sex, or history of previous laparotomy.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to prophylactic intraperitoneal mesh implantation or standard abdominal closure.

Objective.evidence: Objective: To compare the incidence of incisional hernia among patients after prophylactic intraperitoneal mesh implantation with that among patients after standard abdominal closure.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary end point was the incidence of incisional hernia 3 years after surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to prophylactic intraperitoneal mesh implantation or standard abdominal closure.

Number_Randomised.evidence: An open-label randomized clinical trial was performed in 169 patients undergoing elective open abdominal surgery from January 1, 2011, to February 29, 2014.

Number_Analysed.evidence: After the exclusion of 19 patients, 150 patients (81 in the control group and 69 in the mesh group) were studied.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The cumulative incidence of incisional hernia was significantly lower in the mesh group compared with the control group (5 of 69 [7.2%] vs 15 of 81 [18.5%], log-rank test P = .03).

Harms.evidence: Abdominal pain was observed in significantly more patients in the mesh group compared with the control group at 6 weeks (34 of 52 [65%] vs 26 of 59 [44%], P = .04) but not at 12 and 36 months postoperatively.
